awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electric-field Directed Assembly of 3D Chiral Metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Chirality is a fundamental characteristic of living matter. Chiral metamaterials are engineered structures composed of periodic metallodielectric building blocks that exhibit chirality. The resonance of individual building blocks and strong coupling between neighbors allow the realization of exotic electromagnetic properties such as negative refractive index and giant circular dichroism. Chiral metamaterials could revolutionize many modern technologies including superlenses, optical communication, cloaking devices, and high resolution sensors. Three-dimensional chiral metamaterials are, however, extremely difficult to fabricate especially in an economical and large scale fashion. This research will utilize asymmetric particles as building blocks and exploit a time-varying electric field to guide the assembly of these particles into long-range periodic chiral structures. The solution-based process could potentially reduce the fabrication cost significantly. The compatibility of the electrode design with existing microelectronic manufacturing infrastructures will also open the door to commercialize innovative metamaterials for emerging applications. The research team will also engage both high school and undergraduate students with immersive research experiences. Learning modules such as "Colloids, surfactants, and our daily lives" and "Optical technology that changes our lives" will be developed in collaboration with K-12 teachers. The research findings will also be included in the development of several multi-disciplinary courses such as "Engineering of Soft Materials" and "Nanotechnology: From Molecules to Machines". 

The goal of this collaborative project is to use electric fields to assemble Janus metallodielectric particles into a periodic array of chiral clusters as an efficient bottom-up route for making three-dimensional chiral metamaterials. Particles with increasing morphological complexity will be fabricated as building blocks by glancing angle deposition. A liquid electrode cell will be built for the manipulation of the Janus particles via time-varying electric fields in three-dimensions. The Coulomb, dipolar, and electrohydrodynamic interactions will be exploited to guide the assembly of Janus particles into chiral clusters. Further manipulation of the chirality of the electric fields will transform the racemic mixture into enantiomerically pure clusters. The photonic response of the fabricated structures and their applications will be measured and explored in both near-infrared and visible regions. Numerical simulations will also be performed to elucidate the particle assembly mechanisms, their optical properties, and guide experimental optimization. The collaborative and iterative nature of this project will reveal the interrelationship between the design of fundamental building blocks, control of lattice symmetry, and targeted photonic properties of chiral metamaterials.

por.por_cntn:
Chiral metamaterials are engineered sub-wavelength structures composed of periodic metallodielectric building blocks that exhibit chirality. The chiral structures are, however, extremely difficult to fabricate, especially in an economical and large-scale fashion. The major goal of this project is to exploit three-dimensional time-varying electric and magnetic fields to assemble asymmetric particles into a periodic array of single-handed chiral clusters as an efficient bottom-up route for making chiral metamaterials.    

 

We first synthesized the magnetic hybrid dimers based on the two-step emulsion polymerization method in which crosslinked polystyrene seed particles were synthesized first. The second lobe was then generated via swelling the crosslinked seeds by styrene and sodium styrene sulfonate monomers again. Due to the addition of sodium styrene sulfonate, the synthesized PS dimers were negatively charged. The iron oxide nanoparticles functionalized with dopamine (have positive zeta potentials) were then electrostatically adsorbed onto the PS dimers. After the chemical synthesis, we also fully characterized the static and dynamic susceptibilities of those dimers by measuring both magnetic hysteresis diagrams and their rotation speeds under AC magnetic fields. Our synthetic method has the potential to make other types of magnetically anisotropic particles that are useful in colloidal assembly, micromachines, and particulate emulsifiers.    

 

In addition to synthesis, we further showed that these magnetic dimers responded to electric and magnetic fields independently. While the dimer’s orientation can be controlled by a DC magnetic field along the x-y plane, its propulsion speed is solely controlled by the AC electric field applied in the z-direction. Combining both fields, we demonstrated a precise control of the dimer’s trajectory by pre-programming the DC magnetic field along with x and y directions, respectively, via a Matlab code. Our work demonstrates a simple method to control the orientation and speed of micromotors independently and paves the way for the assembly of magnetically anisotropic particles that can be simultaneously controlled by electric and magnetic fields.

 

After understanding the behavior of anisotropic particles under both electric and magnetic fields, we superimposed a vertically applied AC electric field and a planar rotating magnetic field to create chirality clusters with controllable chiralities. For example, by applying the AC electric field itself, we assembled colloidal dimers into left-handed clusters that rotated clockwise due to the electrohydrodynamic torque. When we superimposed a strong magnetic field that rotated counterclockwise, we found that the cluster chirality was preserved, but its rotational direction was switched to counterclockwise, following the direction of the magnetic field but opposite to that driven by the AC electric field. In comparison, the left-handed cluster became unstable and changed its chirality into the right-handed and switched its rotating direction to clockwise as soon as we changed the rotating magnetic field direction from counterclockwise to clockwise. This switch of cluster chirality can be repeated multiple times for different sizes of clusters. Depending on the rotational direction (clockwise or counterclockwise) of the magnetic field, we have successfully made homochiral clusters by converting the unfavored type of enantiomers into another. Based on our experimental observation, we found that the formation of homochiral clusters results from the competition between the electrohydrodynamic torque and magnetic torque.   

 

Beyond experiments, we have also worked on the computational modeling of the assembly of colloidal particles under both electric fields and confinement. In particular, we have modeled the formation of chiral clusters by dimers in response to the electrohydrodynamic interactions. An in-plane rotating field was then used to set the chirality and propel the dimers around the central particle. By tuning the strengths of both the in-plane field and the attractive electrohydrodynamic flow, both rotation direction and chirality of these clusters were reversibly switched by changing the field direction. When isotropic particles are confined between two electrodes, we have discovered various kinds of crystalline lattices and structures via Monte Carlo simulations, which not only faithfully matched our previous experimental results, but also provided new insights on novel structures such as quasicrystals formed by isotropic spherical particles with a single-length-scale Stockmayer potential.

 

Overall, the homochiral colloidal clusters invented in this project can be used for making metamaterials, model systems for studying the separation of chiral molecules, and propellers for microscale transport. This project partially supported three Ph. D. students, one REU undergraduate students, and two undergraduate students at Colorado School of Mines. Two peer-reviewed papers have been published, one manuscript has been submitted, and two additional manuscripts are in preparation. Research findings in this work have been incorporated into a graduate-level course entitled “Engineering of Soft Materials”. The PI and his graduate students also prepared learning modules on colloids, surfactants, and emulsions that were presented to participants in the Summer Camp for Kids with Dyslexia in July 2019 and Summer Workshop on Energy Education for (STEM high school) Teachers in June 2020.
